articles.headline: A Political Comeback: Supply-Side Economics
articles.snippet: The concept of supply-side economics, introduced by Ronald Reagan when he ran for president in 1980, has made a return in this year’s election campaign, in an amended form.
articles.abstract: The concept of supply-side economics, introduced by Ronald Reagan when he ran for president in 1980, has made a return in this year’s election campaign, in an amended form.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Ronald Reagan ran for president in 1980, he promised to cut taxes in what seemed, at the time, a magical way. Tax revenue would go up, not down, he said, as the economy boomed in response to lower rates.

articles.headline: McCain Rejects Broad U.S. Aid on Mortgages
articles.snippet: John McCain drew a sharp distinction with the Democratic presidential candidates, placing some of the blame on homeowners.
articles.abstract: John McCain drew a sharp distinction with the Democratic presidential candidates, placing some of the blame on homeowners.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA ANA, Calif.  Drawing a sharp distinction between himself and the two Democratic presidential candidates, Senator John McCain of Arizona warned Tuesday against vigorous government action to solve the deepening mortgage crisis and the market turmoil it has caused, saying that “it is not the duty of government to bail out and reward those who act irresponsibly, whether they are big banks or small borrowers.”
articles.byline: By Larry Rohter and Edmund L. Andrews

articles.headline: A Chevy With an Engine From China
articles.snippet: Last year, China exported more than $12 billion in auto parts, adding to the problems plaguing North American suppliers, and soon, it will be exporting even more.
articles.abstract: Last year, China exported more than $12 billion in auto parts, adding to the problems plaguing North American suppliers, and soon, it will be exporting even more.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSHAWA, Ontario  General Motors car engines were once the stuff of American legend. The Beach Boys sang, “nothing can touch my 409,” about a powerful Chevy V-8. Oldsmobile owners in 1981 were so angered that their cars had been fitted with Chevrolet engines instead of Oldsmobile “Rockets,” the subject of another hit song, that they successfully sued G.M. over the swap.

articles.headline: Millions of Jobs of a Different Collar
articles.snippet: Politicians talk about the promise of “green collar” jobs. But no one is certain how many such jobs there are, and some don’t agree on what makes a job green.
articles.abstract: Politicians talk about the promise of “green collar” jobs. But no one is certain how many such jobs there are, and some don’t agree on what makes a job green.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERYONE knows what blue-collar and white-collar jobs are, but now a job of another hue  green  has entered the lexicon.

articles.headline: Swift Steps Help Avert Foreclosures in Baltimore
articles.snippet: A group has improved one neighborhood’s foreclosure rate by helping high-risk borrowers to hold on to their homes.
articles.abstract: A group has improved one neighborhood’s foreclosure rate by helping high-risk borrowers to hold on to their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE  When Wilbert and Patricia Savage missed two mortgage payments on their tidy row house here last fall, Mr. Savage, 75, despaired that they could ever catch up.

articles.headline: Banks Balk at Paying for Clear Channel Deal
articles.snippet: Clear Channel and its two private equity buyers may go to court to try and force the banks that had agreed to finance the deal to complete the buyout.
articles.abstract: Clear Channel and its two private equity buyers may go to court to try and force the banks that had agreed to finance the deal to complete the buyout.
articles.lead_paragraph: The $19.5 billion sale of the radio broadcaster Clear Channel Communications to two private equity firms is in jeopardy.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Be It Ever So Illogical: Homeowners Who Won’t Cut the Price
articles.snippet: For both economic and psychological reasons, there is no asset more conducive to hopeful overvaluation than real estate.
articles.abstract: For both economic and psychological reasons, there is no asset more conducive to hopeful overvaluation than real estate.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2005, Randolph Harrison and his wife, Pamela, decided to move north from Silicon Valley, over the Golden Gate Bridge into wooded Marin County to be closer to her new job. They found a six-bedroom house that seemed ideal except for the price, $1.875 million. The current owner, they knew, had bought the house a year earlier for $1.475 million.

articles.headline: Foreign Courts Wary of U.S. Punitive Damages
articles.snippet: For most of the rest of the world, allowing separate awards meant to punish the defendant is a terrible idea.
articles.abstract: For most of the rest of the world, allowing separate awards meant to punish the defendant is a terrible idea.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the late summer of 1985, Kurt Parrott, a 15-year-old who loved baseball and Pac-Man, was thrown from his motorcycle in Opelika, Ala. The buckle of his helmet failed, and he died when his bare head hit the pavement. Mr. Parrott’s mother sued the Italian company that made the helmet, and an Alabama court awarded her $1 million.

articles.headline: Social Site’s New Friends Are Athletes
articles.snippet: Creative Artists Agency is expected to launch WePlay.com, a social networking site for youth sports — something like Facebook for young athletes — in April.
articles.abstract: Creative Artists Agency is expected to launch WePlay.com, a social networking site for youth sports — something like Facebook for young athletes — in April.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last year, Pamela Firestone, the mother of Tony Parker, the San Antonio Spurs point guard, went rooting through her home in Paris and dug up a VHS tape of a 9-year-old Tony on a Parisian basketball court with his two brothers.

articles.headline: Iraqi Crackdown on Shiite Forces Sets Off Fighting
articles.snippet: Heavy fighting broke out in Basra and Baghdad as Iraqi forces mounted a major operation against Shiite militias.
articles.abstract: Heavy fighting broke out in Basra and Baghdad as Iraqi forces mounted a major operation against Shiite militias.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Heavy fighting broke out Tuesday in two of Iraq’s largest cities, as Iraqi ground forces and helicopters mounted a huge operation to break the grip of the Shiite militias controlling Basra, and Iraqi forces clashed with militias in Baghdad. The fighting threatened to destabilize a long-term truce that had helped reduce the level of violence in the five-year-old Iraq war.
articles.byline: By Michael Kamber and James Glanz

articles.headline: The Buzz on the Bus: Pinched, Press Steps Off
articles.snippet: As newspapers slash costs, the presence of relatively few print reporters on candidates’ buses and planes this year is striking.
articles.abstract: As newspapers slash costs, the presence of relatively few print reporters on candidates’ buses and planes this year is striking.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama debated in Cleveland on a snowy evening in late February, 650 journalists descended on the city to follow every jab and parry, albeit on enormous televisions in two makeshift filing centers.

articles.headline: Pay for the Power, Not the Panels
articles.snippet: Some of the most compelling advances in the solar power boom are taking place in financial engineering rather than photovoltaic technology.
articles.abstract: Some of the most compelling advances in the solar power boom are taking place in financial engineering rather than photovoltaic technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: INNOVATION is driving a boom in solar power, but some of the most compelling advances are taking place in financial engineering rather than photovoltaic technology.
